abstract.p: New York attorney general's office says that employees of Renaissance Capital Management Inc, Long Island investment company accused of defrauding nearly 90 people out of $3.2 million, have pleaded guilty to several charges and will all be sentenced by end of month (S)

block.p: The New York attorney general's office said yesterday that the employees of a Long Island investment company accused of defrauding nearly 90 people out of $3.2 million have pleaded guilty to several charges and will all be sentenced by the end of the month.

Vikram Randhawa, top salesman at the company, Renaissance Capital Management Inc. of Farmingdale, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to 2 to 6 years in prison on felony counts of scheming to defraud and grand larceny in the second degree, the attorney general's office said. The company's owner, Allen Andrescu, 26, pleaded guilty to the same charges in August and will be sentenced Oct. 20, the officials said.

The New York attorney general's office said yesterday that the employees of a Long Island investment company accused of defrauding nearly 90 people out of $3.2 million have pleaded guilty to several charges and will all be sentenced by the end of the month.

Vikram Randhawa, top salesman at the company, Renaissance Capital Management Inc. of Farmingdale, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to 2 to 6 years in prison on felony counts of scheming to defraud and grand larceny in the second degree, the attorney general's office said. The company's owner, Allen Andrescu, 26, pleaded guilty to the same charges in August and will be sentenced Oct. 20, the officials said.

Three other employees, Pammi Lamba, Suher Khalfan and Ilamir Ramolia, have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges of selling without a license and were sentenced to conditional releases. Mr. Andrescu and his brokers were accused of promising high returns on investments in a company that they said was about to go public. But the stock was never issued.
